text: on the evening of November 15th with
little warning an illegal tenement
crumpled into a heap in eastern New
Delhi over 70 residents mostly rural
migrant workers were crushed to death
Manoj Sarkar was inside the building why
did I get other
it sounded like rain suddenly everything
came down concrete ceiling fell on and
two men came in and rescue they took me
to the hospital
Sarkar who lost his 10 year old brother
in the collapse says his family was
attracted to the building by the cheap
rents survivors say as many as 400
people were crowded into the ramshackle
building they believe the shoddy
construction was weakened by additional
floors and flooding in the basement the
Builder should be held responsible
because there was water in the basement
he didn't warn us and tell us to
evacuate and he kept constructing more
flowers illegal buildings are
mushrooming all over the impoverished
neighborhoods of New Delhi as millions
of Indians have moved to the cities for
work housing construction has not kept
pace with a growing demand desperate for
shelter migrants are willing to live in
hastily constructed in dangerously
overcrowded housing as long as it's
cheap
while corrupt and greedy landlords risk
hundreds of lives by ignoring building
codes that are rarely enforced by the
Municipal Corporation of Delhi or MCD
this entire colony despite the fact that
it's illegal to construct more than
three floors is full of buildings which
are four or five storeys high it's
because the MCD and police have been
bribed the building's owner Amrit Singh
was notorious for flouting building
rules Singh claims that he bribed
inspectors to avoid paying penalties for
adding floors to his rental buildings he
was recently arrested on homicide
charges related to the building collapse
ironically it is a tenant in one of
Singh's buildings who has come to his
defense we never thought this would
happen so we still consider the Builder
a good person the building suddenly
collapsed he didn't do this
intentionally so I don't think it's his
fault nari on Sharma a carpenter from
Bihar says poor people are grateful to
landlords like saying slumlord or not he
provides one of the few affordable
housing options in New Delhi Sharma only
earns a few thousand rupees or around
175 dollars a month he his wife and
three children used to share a single 10
foot by 10 foot room for about $50 a
month all those living in the building
were labourers poor people used to go
there to find cheap housing if you go to
the other parts of the colony rooms are
not available for rent
I tried four five times but I didn't get
a single room but the building collapse
has had a chilling effect on the housing
market government officials are
demanding investigations into legal
construction the way unauthorised
buildings are being made in Delhi an
inquiry should be made into this whoever
comes into the light through the
investigation it should be punished
officials have begun to crack down on
housing violations and tenants have been
evicted from unsafe buildings but it's
made matters worse but nowhere else to
go many of the poor have been forced in
community shelters or onto the streets I
don't have anything to say I'm a simple
laborer I don't know what the government
and the owner will do for us they told
us to evacuate so we evacuated and now
we're homeless
you
